thread.title: Hurricane Katrina: New Orleans 10 years later
thread.title_full: Hurricane Katrina: New Orleans 10 years later - MarketWatch

author: MarketWatch
title: Hurricane Katrina: New Orleans 10 years later
text:
Getty Images Slide 1 of 12 At left, Hurricane Katrina survivor Robert Green in front of his new home, constructed by the Make It Right Foundation, in the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans. His mother and granddaughter perished after clinging to the roof during flooding of their former home on the same location in the Lower Ninth. The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, which killed at least 1,836 people and is considered the costliest natural disaster in U.S. history, is Aug. 29. But 10 years later, many survivors have left and never returned, others are still rebuilding, and much of the city’s Lower Ninth Ward remains uninhabited.
Getty Images Slide 2 of 12 Students attend dance class at the Encore Academy charter school May 13 in New Orleans. More than 100 schools in the city were damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. Following Katrina, New Orleans’ decimated public school system was almost entirely revamped and now approximately 94% of city students attend independently run charter schools. Encore Academy’s performing arts focused program is outpacing most other open admission charter schools in academic performance in the city.
Getty Images Slide 3 of 12 Graduates of McDonogh No. 35 Senior High School in New Orleans stand at their commencement at the Ernest N. Memorial Convention Center in May. Thousands of Hurricane Katrina survivors attempted to use the convention center as a shelter of last resort in the days following the storm, yet it lacked power, water, food and medical supplies. McDonogh No. 35 was damaged by flooding from Hurricane Katrina and was the first high school for African-Americans in the state of Louisiana. It is one of the last remaining traditional public schools in the city.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 4 of 12 Barry sits beneath an overpass May 12 in New Orleans. While Hurricane Katrina drove many in the city into homelessness, New Orleans has recently become the first city in the nation to declare an end to veteran homelessness.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 5 of 12 Club members march past the historic Carver Theater, named for former slave and famed botanist and inventor George Washington Carver, during the Zulu Social Aid and Pleasure Club second line parade on May 17 in New Orleans. Traditional second line parades are put on by social aid and pleasure clubs organized by neighborhood in New Orleans. The parades represent a history of solidarity, empowerment and cultural pride within the African-American enclaves of the city.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 6 of 12 Kids jump rope at the Sobaluavro family home after the Zulu Social Aid and Pleasure Club second line parade in May in New Orleans.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 7 of 12 A woman walks along the rebuilt Industrial Canal levee wall in the Lower Ninth Ward in May 2015 in New Orleans. The levee was destroyed during Hurricane Katrina and people have been slowly moving back to the devastated neighborhood ever since.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 8 of 12 A tractor seeds the side of an earthen levee recently in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana. A new program is “armoring” 80 miles of earthen levees in the region with a combination Bermuda grass grown from sod and reinforced mats. The measure protects against levee erosion.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 9 of 12 French volunteers with lowernine.org help rebuild a home heavily damaged by Hurricane Katrina flooding in New Orleans’ Lower Ninth Ward in May of this year. Residents continue to slowly return to the Lower Ninth Ward, although much of the area remains uninhabited.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 10 of 12 A storm gate stands as construction continues on the 17th Street Canal pump station this spring in New Orleans. The 17th Street Canal levee was breached during Hurricane Katrina and the Army Corps of Engineers are rebuilding the regional levee system.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 11 of 12 Esther Joseph sweeps in her flood-damaged home which is still being rebuilt in the Lower Ninth Ward, 10 years later. She hopes to move into the house when completed by the end of this year.
Mario Tama/Getty Images Slide 12 of 12 Esther Joseph sweeps in her flood-damaged home which is still being rebuilt in the Lower Ninth Ward, 10 years later. She hopes to move into the house when completed by the end of this year.
